awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Molecular Simulation Methods to Probe RNA Dynamics, Thermodynamics, and Interfacial Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract - Vashisth - 1554558

Ribonucleic acid (RNA) molecules are not passive information carriers but molecules with versatile chemical and physical properties that can be exploited for therapeutic, synthetic biology, materials, bio-sensing, and engineering applications. Underlying all these applications are the dynamics which encompass a large number of modes, span vast spatiotemporal scales, and are connected to the intrinsic structural features (e.g. base-pairing) and some extrinsic factors (e.g. ligand binding). While equilibrium fluctuations in biomolecules such as RNA are inherent, it is the large-scale conformational transitions that play a dominant role in interfacial processes such as biomolecular recognition. Such dynamic properties are encoded in the physical free energy landscapes of biomolecules, the robust sampling of which can provide key thermodynamic and kinetic information on functional conformational ensembles of RNA molecules. The PI plans to look at conformational dynamics and interfacial interactions in small RNA molecules to enable their use for the above mentioned applications.

The research proposed is broadly concerned with two questions: (1) What physical variables are responsible for local and global conformational transitions in RNA molecules? and (2) How do these conformational transitions facilitate interfacial interactions of RNA with a diverse group of ligands (small molecules, short peptides, and globular proteins)? To gain a holistic view of the dynamics and interactions, the modeling and simulation effort will be integrated with spectroscopic (nucleic magnetic resonance) and imaging (electron cryo-microscopy) data. Understanding the details of how biomolecules undergo large-scale structural changes to elicit function is an unsolved problem. It is known that biomolecules are flexible and understanding their dynamics may provide insights into their function. Though, it is challenging to characterize such dynamic motions because no single computational or experimental technique can resolve motions at all spatiotemporal scales. The proposed computational approaches use physical free-energy landscapes in a reduced set of coordinates (while maintaining the all atom representation) as opposed to all degrees-of-freedom. The combination of computational and experimental techniques could establish new approaches to study these dynamics at a wide spectrum of time and length scales.

The educational plan will bring molecular theories, numerical algorithms, and visualization tools to a broad spectrum of STEM students and educators. It could impact and meet the Next Generation Science Standards and broaden participation in engineering and biophysics, through a broader educational initiative devoted to impart "visuospatial" thinking as a key skill via workshops on a freely-available software tool that will be further developed and disseminated via training of a wide spectrum of STEM population (students, teachers, and faculty). The students will travel to regional and national conferences, and will be exposed to international mentoring and multicultural experiences through partnerships with flagship engineering schools in India.

por.por_cntn:
RNA molecules are known to catalyze complex reactions and play a fundamental role in many biological processes and technological applications. These versatile functions of RNA molecules relate to out-of-equilibrium and large-scale conformational motions, often termed “rare transitions” occurring at various spatiotemporal scales, that also facilitate interfacial processes involving recognition of small ligands, peptides, and proteins. This CAREER project developed a novel and transformative research and education program to understand dynamics and interfacial interactions in small viral RNA molecules using all-atom computer simulation methods and advanced sampling algorithms in combination with data from experimental techniques.

The intellectual merit of this project is embodied in development and applications of several enhanced sampling simulation methods to uncover molecular scale details of RNA conformational dynamics at local and global levels as well as an atomic-scale mapping of RNA interfacial interactions with small-molecules, peptides, and antiviral proteins. We made several significant advances in development and applications of these enhanced sampling methods: (1) we conducted large-scale simulations of a viral RNA molecule in 27 unique states with ligands of various sizes and discovered significant conformational heterogeneity utilized by viral RNA in recognizing a diverse set of ligand molecules; (2) we applied non-equilibrium simulation methods in combination with thermodynamic calculations to reveal that rare conformational transitions in nucleobases are responsible for small-molecule ligand recognition; (3) we developed and applied collective variable based sampling methods to study local flipping of bases and characterized complex reaction coordinates to study these transitions; (4) we extended applications of non-equilibrium methods to study peptide ligands and revealed the importance of salt-bridging interactions in RNA/peptide binding; (5) We developed and applied free energy based simulation methods to discover key interfacial interactions between RNA and lab-evolved proteins, RNA and helical peptides, and RNA and antiviral proteins; and (6) We developed guidance on further broader applications of these methods to study thermodynamics and kinetics in other RNA molecules. These research outcomes were reported in multiple journal publications, conference presentations, methodology focused workshops, and shared via data sharing platforms. Collectively, these methodological developments and applications resulted in advanced computational tools and new molecular scale insights into interactions and structural adaptations in RNA molecules governing their biological functions and technological utility.

The education program and broader impact activities of this project impacted training of PhD students, several undergraduate researchers, and postdoctoral scholars. These researchers conducted large-scale simulations, utilized high performance computing resources, and presented their findings at local, regional, and national conferences and won research presentation awards, leading to their significant professional development. The core concepts from the project led to significant enhancements of STEM courses in chemical engineering, bioengineering, and biophysics. Moreover, a series of molecular visualization workshops that were offered for high school students, graduate students, university faculty, and middle/high-school teachers, led to training of a diverse STEM workforce in biomolecular modeling, simulation, and visualization. Overall, the research, education, and broader impact activities of this CAREER project led to impactful advances in new computer simulation methods of broader utility, and a transformative impact on training and education of a diverse STEM workforce in engineering and scientific disciplines.
